parameter.name: maxtries
parameter.p:
Physics Of Unicycling
As described in the video, the three forces primarily involved with unicycling are gravity, a normal force, and friction. In order to turn, a unicyclist (or a biker) may try a technique called countersteering. Which of the following offers a correct explanation for the process of by which a unicyclist can countersteer to make a turn?

choicegroup.choice: First steer towards the desired direction so that friction primarily acts towards the correct direction.
First steer opposite the desired direction so that friction primarily acts radially inward.
First steer towards the desired direction so that friction primarily acts radially inward.
First steer opposite the desired direction so that friction primarily acts towards the correct direction.

solved.p: Explanation: countersteering involves steering in the opposite direction to begin a turn. This causes the unicyclist to lean to the inside of the turn (radially inward). Friction thus primary acts as a centripetal force, but this also causes a large torque about the center of mass. The leaning is necessary to make torque from the normal force partially offset the torque due to friction.
